channel.title: Virus?
channel.description: I just got a message saying ' You runescape account has been hacked. ' In like a little theme box. Even though I don't even play Runescape.. I think it has to do with the trojan from the server in Server Downloads section that got deleted i think.. When I ran that server as a test because he said it contained a trojan, a second screen popped up, but closed quickly.. I ran AVG multiple times, and it doesn't find any viruses...

item.title: Virus?

item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

^ Yeah. My dumb ass dled it to make sure -.-. It’s all good, it’s gone. Requesting for a lock.

Read full topic

item.title: Virus?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:11, topic:416428”][code]Malwarebytes’ Anti-Malware 1.51.2.1300

Malwarebytes

Free Antivirus Replacement & Anti-Malware Tool

Malwarebytes protects you against malware, ransomware, and other advanced online threats that have made traditional antivirus obsolete and ineffective. Download Malwarebytes for free and secure your PC, Mac and Android.

(No malicious items detected)

HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\VB and VBA Program Settings\SrvID (Malware.Trace) -> Quarantined and deleted successfully.

Registry Values Infected:
(No malicious items detected)

(No malicious items detected)

Folders Infected:
(No malicious items detected)

Files Infected:
c:\Users\rodrigo\AppData\Roaming\WinDir\Svchost.exe (Trojan.Agent) -> Quarantined and deleted successfully.
[/code]

Lol.

But when I start up my computer again, it says the same thing…[/quote]
Could be that the guy literally programmed it to make a message popup just to scare you, and it actually doesn’t do anything other than that, therefore can not be classed as harmful.
If you haven’t already done so, check your msconfig startup items in case there’s anything unwanted in there.

Read full topic

item.title: Virus?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Fridder:

Shut down your computer by either unplugging it from the back or holding the power button until it shuts down. Then, it should say ‘Windows has not shut down properly’ or something. It should show these options or something similar to these options:

Or be smart and press F8 on boot instead of potentially harming your baby.

Read full topic

item.title: Virus?
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

[quote=“Hot_Potato, post:9, topic:416428”][quote author=Fridder link=topic=518341.msg3766816#msg3766816 date=1317318427]

I thinks server downloads should be approved before posted.

Sounds like a great idea, but it would be a pain in the ass to download every single server that gets posted.
[/quote]
They could make a system maybe?[/quote]

Maybe scan their files before the files are uploaded, like mediafire.

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:8, topic:416428”]Windows x64

I’m running it atm. How do I get into safe mode?[/quote]

Shut down your computer by either unplugging it from the back or holding the power button until it shuts down. Then, it should say ‘Windows has not shut down properly’ or something. It should show these options or something similar to these options:

Windows Advanced Options Menu
Please select an option:

Safe Mode
Safe Mode with Networking
Safe Mode with Command Prompt

Start Windows Normally
Reboot

Use the up and down arrow keys to move the highlight to your choice.

Scroll to ‘Safe Mode’ then press enter. It should start your computer up, except the screen will be really big. Ignore the big screen and scan your computer with malwarebytes. Or, if you were unable to download malwarebytes, then select ‘Safe Mode with Networking’ instead of ‘Safe Mode’.

Read full topic

item.title: Virus?
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:4, topic:416428”][quote author=Fridder link=topic=518341.msg3766800#msg3766800 date=1317317882]
Get Malwarebytes’. Run your computer in Safe mode that way the virus doesn’t open on start-up.
[/quote]
How do I do that?[/quote]

What is your current OS?

Malwarebytes

Free Antivirus Replacement & Anti-Malware Tool

Malwarebytes protects you against malware, ransomware, and other advanced online threats that have made traditional antivirus obsolete and ineffective. Download Malwarebytes for free and secure your PC, Mac and Android.
